_meta.title: UK Chancellor Simulation - Economic Model Parameters
_meta.description: Calibrated economic parameters for a UK fiscal policy simulation game, derived from IMF, OBR, Bank of England, and academic research.

units.multipliers: Change in GDP per unit change in fiscal instrument (dimensionless ratio)
units.elasticities: Percentage change in outcome per percentage change in input
units.monetary: GBP billions (2024 prices) unless otherwise noted

fiscalMultipliers._description: How £1 of fiscal policy change affects GDP. Values represent cumulative impact multipliers. Sources: IMF Fiscal Monitor (2010, 2012), Blanchard & Leigh (2013), OBR fiscal multipliers (2023), Ramey (2019) survey.

taxMultipliers._note: Tax multipliers are typically negative: a tax INCREASE reduces GDP. Values shown as absolute magnitude; apply negative sign for tax increases.

incomeTax.source: OBR certified model; consistent with Romer & Romer (2010) finding of -1.0 to -3.0 for US but UK open-economy leakage reduces this. Mountford & Uhlig (2009) find lower values for open economies.

vat.source: OBR model. VAT changes pass through quickly to prices. Crossley, Low & Sleeman (2014) study of 2008 UK VAT cut found significant spending response.

corporationTax.source: Corporation tax has slower, more uncertain effects working through investment. OBR model; Mertens & Ravn (2013). Long-run effects are larger as capital stock adjusts.

nationalInsurance.source: Similar to income tax but split between employer (affecting labour demand) and employee (affecting take-home pay). OBR model.

capitalGainsTax.source: Small base, high behavioural response. Significant forestalling/avoidance effects. HMRC behavioural analysis.

fuelDuty.source: Regressive, affects transport costs. Short-run demand relatively inelastic. OBR ready reckoner.

councilTax.source: Broad-based, unavoidable. Effects on lower-income households give higher marginal propensity to consume effect.

currentSpending.source: OBR model; Ramey (2011); Auerbach & Gorodnichenko (2012). Direct demand injection but crowding-out reduces long-run effect.

capitalInvestment._description: Infrastructure, buildings, equipment - includes productive capacity effects
capitalInvestment.source: IMF World Economic Outlook (2014) Chapter 3 found multipliers of 1.5+ for public investment in advanced economies. Abiad, Furceri & Topalova (2016). Higher because it adds to productive capacity.

transferPayments._description: Benefits, pensions, universal credit, tax credits
transferPayments.source: Recipients have high marginal propensity to consume. Brewer, Saez & Shephard (2010). Johnson, Parker & Souleles (2006). Slightly lower than current spending because of saving leakage.

nhs._description: NHS spending - politically salient, directly employs ~1.4m people
nhs.source: Large employer with domestic supply chains. Claxton et al (2015) on NHS productivity. Similar to current spending but higher employment intensity.

defence._description: Defence spending - significant import leakage for equipment
defence.source: Import content reduces domestic multiplier. Barro & Redlick (2011). Domestic employment effects remain significant.

education._description: Education spending - long-run human capital effects
education.source: Long-run returns through human capital accumulation. Hanushek & Woessmann (2012). Short-run similar to current spending; long-run productivity gains.

stateDependent._description: Multipliers vary significantly with the state of the economy. Auerbach & Gorodnichenko (2012, 2013) is the key reference.

recessionMultiplierScaling.source: Auerbach & Gorodnichenko (2012) find spending multipliers of ~2.5 in recessions vs ~0.0 in expansions for US. Baum, Poplawski-Ribeiro & Weber (2012) find similar for EU. Scale factor applied to base multipliers above.

zeroBoundAmplification.source: Christiano, Eichenbaum & Rebelo (2011); Woodford (2011). When interest rates are at zero lower bound, monetary policy cannot offset fiscal changes, so multipliers are larger.

fiscalConsolidationInRecession.warning: IMF (2012) acknowledged underestimating fiscal multipliers during European austerity. Blanchard & Leigh (2013) showed actual multipliers were 0.9-1.7 vs assumed 0.5.
fiscalConsolidationInRecession.source: Blanchard & Leigh (2013) 'Growth Forecast Errors and Fiscal Multipliers', IMF Working Paper.

openEconomyAdjustments._description: UK is an open economy (~30% trade/GDP). Import leakage reduces domestic multipliers.

exchangeRateOffset._note: Fiscal expansion can depreciate currency (via expected future taxes) or appreciate it (via interest rates). Net effect uncertain.
exchangeRateOffset.source: Mundell-Fleming model suggests fiscal expansion appreciates currency under floating rates, but UK experience is mixed. Corsetti, Meier & Muller (2012).

inflationSensitivity._description: How policy actions and shocks feed through to inflation. Bank of England targeting 2% CPI.

demandPullInflation._interpretation: A 1 percentage point positive output gap adds ~0.3pp to inflation per year

lagStructure._note: Peak impact at 6-8 quarters. Full pass-through takes ~2 years.

demandPullInflation.source: Bank of England Quarterly Model; Batini & Haldane (1999); Bean (2006).

energyPricePassThrough._interpretation: Energy is ~7% of CPI basket directly
energyPricePassThrough._interpretation2: A 10% energy price rise adds ~1.5pp to core inflation over 12 months via supply chains
energyPricePassThrough.source: ONS CPI weights; Millard & Sheredy (2019); Forbes, Kirkham & Sheredy (2021).

importPricePassThrough._interpretation: A 10% sterling depreciation adds ~2.5pp to CPI over 2-3 years
importPricePassThrough.source: Forbes (2015) 'Much ado about something'; Campa & Goldberg (2005). UK pass-through has increased post-Brexit.

wagePriceSpiral._interpretation: A 1pp rise in wage growth adds ~0.2pp to inflation
wagePriceSpiral._interpretation2: A 1pp rise in inflation adds ~0.35pp to wage growth expectations
wagePriceSpiral.source: Broadbent (2022); Haldane (2017). Second-round effects are key concern for BoE.

phillipsCurve._description: Relationship between unemployment and inflation for the UK
phillipsCurve._interpretation: A 1pp fall in unemployment below NAIRU adds ~0.3pp to inflation
phillipsCurve._interpretation2: 60% of inflation determination is from expectations, 40% from slack

flatteningTrend.source: Hooper, Mishkin & Sufi (2020); Miles, Panizza & Reis (2017). UK evidence in Broadbent (2017).

phillipsCurve.source: Ball & Mazumder (2011); Blanchard (2016). UK specific estimates from Nickell (2003), Bell & Blanchflower (2018).

monetaryPolicyReaction._description: How Bank of England responds to inflation (affects game's interest rate environment)

taylorRuleCoefficients.source: Taylor (1993); Clarida, Gali & Gertler (1998). Neutral rate estimate from BoE (2023) suggesting R* of ~1-1.5% real, plus 2% inflation target.

monetaryPolicyReaction._note: BoE estimates monetary policy takes 18-24 months for full transmission

marketReactions._description: How financial markets respond to fiscal policy. Critical for game realism after 2022 mini-budget.

debtToGdpSensitivity._interpretation: Each 1pp rise in debt-to-GDP adds ~3bp to 10-year gilt yields

above120pct._note: Significant risk premium, approaching danger zone

debtToGdpSensitivity.source: Laubach (2009); Engen & Hubbard (2005) find 2-5bp per 1pp debt/GDP for US. Afonso (2010) for European estimates. UK benefits from reserve currency status and long avg maturity.

deficitSensitivity._interpretation: Each 1pp rise in deficit-to-GDP adds ~8bp to gilt yields
deficitSensitivity.source: Ardagna, Caselli & Lane (2007); Faini (2006). Flow of new borrowing matters alongside stock.

fiscalCredibility._interpretation: Having credible fiscal rules reduces yields by ~50bp vs no framework

ruleBreakingPenalty._note: Penalty for breaking announced fiscal rules

fiscalCredibility.source: Debrun, Hauner & Kumar (2009); IMF (2009) on fiscal institutions. UK experience with OBR since 2010.

marketSentimentShock.trigger: Unfunded fiscal expansion exceeding market expectations by >2% GDP
marketSentimentShock.source: September-October 2022 gilt crisis. 30-year yields rose ~160bp in days. Bank of England emergency intervention required.

creditRatings._description: Sovereign credit rating triggers based on UK historical experience

historicalChanges.reason: Subdued growth prospects, rising debt burden, challenges to fiscal consolidation
Weaker economic and fiscal outlook, delayed deficit reduction

Brexit uncertainty, risk to economic outlook
Fiscal weakening, Brexit uncertainty eroding institutional strength

High but stabilising debt, credible fiscal framework

downgradeTriggers.debtToGdpRising: Sustained rise in debt-to-GDP above 100% without credible stabilisation plan
downgradeTriggers.deficitPersistence: Structural deficit above 3% of GDP for 3+ years
downgradeTriggers.growthShock: Sustained GDP growth below 1% reducing tax revenues
downgradeTriggers.institutionalWeakening: Undermining BoE independence or OBR credibility
downgradeTriggers.politicalInstability: Inability to deliver fiscal plans due to political dysfunction
downgradeTriggers.source: Rating agency methodology documents: Moody's Sovereign Rating Methodology (2019), S&P Sovereign Rating Methodology (2017), Fitch Sovereign Rating Criteria (2020).

ratingImpactOnYields.source: Afonso, Furceri & Gomes (2012); Cantor & Packer (1996). UK impact moderated by deep, liquid gilt market.

fiscalExpansionImpact._interpretation: Each 1% GDP unfunded fiscal expansion depreciates sterling ~2%
fiscalExpansionImpact.fundedExpansionImpact: Approximately neutral - depends on growth vs borrowing balance

interestRateDifferentialImpact._interpretation: Each 1pp UK rate above US rate appreciates sterling ~4%

growthSensitivities._description: How various policy levers and conditions affect UK GDP growth

businessConfidence._interpretation: A 10% rise in business confidence index leads to ~15% rise in business investment over 2 years

confidenceDrivers._note: Weights summing to 1.0 for composite confidence index

businessConfidence.source: Bloom (2009) on uncertainty; Baker, Bloom & Davis (2016) Economic Policy Uncertainty Index. CBI Industrial Trends Survey evidence.

corporationTax._interpretation: A 1pp rise in corporation tax reduces FDI inflows by ~0.7%
corporationTax._interpretation2: A 1pp rise in corporation tax reduces domestic business investment by ~0.4%

rateToGrowthEffect._interpretation: A 1pp rise in corp tax reduces growth by 0.02pp short-run, 0.05pp long-run per year

corporationTax.source: Devereux & Griffith (2003); De Mooij & Ederveen (2003) meta-analysis of 25 studies finds semi-elasticity of FDI to tax of -3.3. OECD (2010). Suarez Serrato & Zidar (2016).

rateToGDPEffect._interpretation: A 1pp rise in Bank Rate reduces GDP by ~0.3% after 18 months

channels._note: Share of transmission through each channel

interestRates.source: Bank of England Quarterly Bulletin (2012) 'The transmission mechanism of monetary policy'; Cloyne & Huertgen (2016).

lafferCurve._description: Tax rates at which revenues begin declining due to behavioural response

revenueMaximisingTopRate._unit: Percent marginal rate (combined income tax + NI)

taxableIncomeElasticity._interpretation: A 1% rise in (1-tax rate) increases reported taxable income by this percentage

incomeTax.source: Saez, Slemrod & Giertz (2012) survey finds ETI of 0.12-0.40. Brewer, Saez & Shephard (2010) for UK. HMRC (2012) find top rate ETI of 0.45-0.48 supporting 45p rate over 50p.

corporationTax.source: Clausing (2007); Devereux (2007). OECD average ~23%. Competitive pressure from Ireland (12.5%), suggesting UK maximum is constrained by international competition.

capitalGainsTax.behaviouralResponse: Very high - significant timing, avoidance, and emigration responses
capitalGainsTax.source: Agersnap & Zidar (2021); HMRC CGT behavioural analysis. Very sensitive to lock-in effects and international mobility.

historicalTrends._unit: Percent per year, output per hour

productivityPuzzleFactors: Zombie firms surviving in low-rate environment

policyImpactOnProductivity._interpretation: A 10% rise in public R&D spending eventually raises productivity growth by ~1pp
policyImpactOnProductivity.source: Haskel & Wallis (2013); Crafts (2009) on UK infrastructure. OBR (2023) assumptions on trend productivity growth.

productivityGrowth.source: ONS productivity statistics; Tenreyro (2018) on UK productivity puzzle; Haldane (2017) 'Productivity Puzzles'.

brexitGDPHit._unit: Percent of GDP over 15 years vs remaining in EU
brexitGDPHit._note: Structural reduction in trade openness and investment

tradeElasticity._interpretation: UK imports are more sensitive to growth than exports (structural trade deficit)

tradeAndBrexit.source: OBR (2020 and 2023) Brexit impact assessment; Dhingra et al (2017) CEP Brexit Analysis; UK Government (2018) Long-Term Economic Analysis.

labourMarket._description: UK labour market dynamics and relationships

okunsLaw._interpretation: A 1pp fall in GDP growth raises unemployment by ~0.35pp
okunsLaw._interpretation2: A 1pp rise in unemployment corresponds to ~2.86% GDP below potential
okunsLaw._note: UK labour market is relatively flexible by European standards, so Okun coefficient is between US (~0.5) and continental Europe (~0.2)
okunsLaw.source: Ball, Leigh & Loungani (2017); Lee (2000) for UK estimates. OBR employment forecasting model.

nairu._note: NAIRU has fallen due to labour market reforms (1980s-90s), flexible labour market, and gig economy. But estimates are highly uncertain.

naturalRate.source: Sheredy & Sheredy (2022); Ball & Mankiw (2002). BoE Monetary Policy Report estimates.

wageGrowth._interpretation: A 1pp fall in unemployment below NAIRU raises wage growth by ~0.45pp
wageGrowth._interpretation2: A 1pp rise in inflation expectations raises wage demands by ~0.40pp
wageGrowth._interpretation3: Approx 30% of wage growth is driven by productivity growth in the long run

minimumWageEffect._interpretation: NLW is ~60% of median hourly pay (one of the highest bite ratios in OECD)
minimumWageEffect._interpretation2: A 10% rise in minimum wage may reduce covered employment by ~1%
minimumWageEffect.source: Dube (2019); Low Pay Commission analysis; Manning (2021).

publicSectorPayPremium._interpretation: Public sector pays ~5% more than private sector on average (varying by occupation and including pensions)
publicSectorPayPremium._interpretation2: A 1pp rise in public sector pay settlement feeds ~0.3pp into private sector settlements

wageGrowth.source: Bell & Blanchflower (2018, 2020); Haldane (2017); ONS ASHE data.

economicInactivity.source: ONS Labour Force Survey; IFS (2023) on post-COVID inactivity; Health Foundation (2023).

policyResponse._unit: GBP billions peak exposure (RBS, Lloyds, Bradford & Bingley, Northern Rock)

financialCrisis2008.source: ONS GDP data; OBR Historical public finances databank; Bank of England statistical database; Darling (2011) 'Back from the Brink'.

keyMetrics._note: Roughly 80:20 spending cuts to tax rises ratio

giltYields10Year._note: Yields fell, but driven largely by global factors and QE rather than fiscal credibility alone

debateAndLessons.proAusterity: Restored market confidence, reduced deficit, gilt yields fell
debateAndLessons.antiAusterity: Unnecessarily slowed recovery, multipliers were larger than Treasury assumed, GDP only recovered pre-crisis levels in 2014
debateAndLessons.imfReassessment: IMF (2012, 2013) acknowledged multipliers were 2-3x larger than initially assumed during consolidation
debateAndLessons.obrReassessment: OBR later estimated austerity reduced GDP growth by 1-1.5pp per year in 2011-2013

austerity2010to2015.source: OBR Economic and Fiscal Outlooks 2010-2015; IFS Green Budget series; Born, Muller & Pfeifer (2020); Wren-Lewis (2016).

keyMetrics._unit4: Percent of GDP (crossed 100% for first time since 1960s)
keyMetrics._unit5: GBP billions (direct spending and tax measures)

furloughScheme.unemploymentWithout: OECD estimated UK unemployment could have reached 13-15% without furlough

giltYields._note: Yields stayed low despite massive borrowing due to BoE QE (£450bn total)

covidResponse2020.source: ONS GDP data; OBR (2021) COVID fiscal analysis; NAO (2021) COVID cost tracker; BoE QE data.

aftermath._unit: Basis points estimated permanent 'Truss premium' on gilts
aftermath._unit2: GBP per year for average new mortgage
credibilityLessons: OBR scrutiny essential for market confidence
Fiscal rules must be maintained or clearly replaced
Unfunded tax cuts treated differently from unfunded spending (ideological signal)

trussMinibudget2022.source: Bank of England Financial Stability Report (2022); OBR (2022) November EFO; House of Commons Treasury Committee inquiry; IFS analysis.

modelParameters._description: Derived parameters for the simulation engine, combining the above into usable game mechanics

gdpCalculation._unit: Percent per year, UK trend growth (OBR estimate 2024)
gdpCalculation.formula: growth = baseGrowth + fiscalImpulse + monetaryImpulse + externalShocks + confidenceEffect

deficitCalculation._interpretation: A 1% rise in GDP raises tax revenues by ~1.05% (slightly greater than 1 due to progressive taxes)
deficitCalculation._interpretation2: A 1% rise in GDP reduces government spending by ~0.2% (automatic stabilisers: unemployment benefits, etc.)
deficitCalculation._interpretation3: Automatic stabilisers offset ~50% of GDP fluctuations on the fiscal balance
deficitCalculation.source: OBR (2023) fiscal multipliers and ready reckoners; Girouard & Andre (2005) OECD methodology.

debtDynamics.formula: debt_ratio(t+1) = debt_ratio(t) * (1 + interest_rate - growth_rate) / (1 + growth_rate) + primary_deficit(t)

interestRateGrowthDifferential._note: When r-g is negative, debt ratios are easier to stabilise. Current positive r-g makes fiscal consolidation harder.

debtMaturityProtection._unit: Years (UK has one of longest average maturities among advanced economies)
debtMaturityProtection._unit2: Percent of total debt rolled over annually
debtMaturityProtection._note: Long maturity insulates budget from interest rate spikes but means rates eventually feed through

debtDynamics.source: DMO Annual Review; OBR Fiscal Risks Report (2023); Mehrotra & Sergeyev (2021).

policySensitivities._description: Quick-reference lookup: how policy changes map to outcomes

incomeTax1pChange._unit: GBP billions per 1p on basic rate
incomeTax1pChange.source: OBR ready reckoners (2023). Higher rate 1p change yields ~£2bn.

vatChange1pp._unit: GBP billions per 1pp on standard rate
vatChange1pp.source: OBR ready reckoners; ONS CPI calculation methodology.

corporationTaxChange1pp.source: OBR ready reckoners (2023); HMRC corporation tax statistics.

publicSectorPayRise1pp._unit: GBP billions per 1pp across all public sector

benefitUprating1pp._unit: GBP billions per 1pp above baseline indexation
benefitUprating1pp.distributionalImpact: Strongly progressive - benefits lowest quintile most
benefitUprating1pp.source: OBR ready reckoners; DWP benefit expenditure tables.

capitalInvestment1bnIncrease._note: Only capital spending has permanent supply-side effect

eventTriggers._description: Conditions that trigger special events in the game

conditions: Unfunded fiscal expansion > 2% GDP without OBR forecast

Breaking fiscal rules combined with poor growth outlook

startingConditions2024._description: Approximate initial conditions if game starts in 2024/25
startingConditions2024.source: OBR Economic and Fiscal Outlook (March 2024); ONS; BoE.
